description: From Middle English gele, from Old French gelee (“frost”), from early Medieval Latin gelāta, from Latin gelāre (“freeze”).

entries.meaning: (New Zealand, Australia, Britain) A dessert made by boiling gelatine, sugar and some flavouring (often derived from fruit) and allowing it to set, known as "jello" in North America.

(Canada, US, Britain (certain specific usages)) A clear or translucent fruit preserve, made from fruit juice and set using either naturally occurring, or added, pectin. Normally known as "jam" in Commonwealth English but see redcurrant jelly and jeely
examples: Perfect jelly is of appetizing flavor; beautifully colored and translucent; tender enough to cut easily with a spoon, yet firm enough to hold its shape when turned from the glass.

entries.meaning: A savoury substance, derived from meat, that has the same texture as the dessert.
Any substance or object having the consistency of jelly.

examples: Species of the phylum Cnidaria – the classic jelly – have existed in something close to their current form for at least 565 million years; Ctenophora, the comb jellies, are not much younger.

entries.meaning: (slang, now rare) A pretty girl; a girlfriend.
examples: ‘Gowan goes to Oxford a lot,’ the boy said. ‘He′s got a jelly there.’

entries.meaning: (US, slang) A large backside, especially a woman's.
examples: I shake my jelly at every chance / When I whip with my hips you slip into a trance
Mary Alice gazed at a picture of herself wearing jellies and an oversized turquoise T-shirt that matched her eyes  […]

verbs.description: jelly (third-person singular simple present jellies, present participle jellying, simple past and past participle jellied)

adjectives.description: jelly (comparative more jelly, superlative most jelly)

examples: "I think other people make rude comments because they're jelly [jealous] bro," Schroer said. "We're just showing our love to other people."

entries.meaning: (India) Vitrified brick refuse used as metal in building roads.
examples: Under pinning with jelly in chunam — one square.
